references: Westcott, P. W. 1969. Relationships among the three species of jays wintering in southeastern Arizona. Condor 71:353-359.

Moriarty, D. J., R. E. Farris, D. K. Noda, and P. A. Stanton. 1985. Effects of fire on a coastal sage scrub bird community. Southwest. Nat. 30:452-453.
Lawrence, G. E. 1966. Ecology of vertebrate animals in relation to chaparral fire in the Sierra Nevada foothills. Ecology 47:278-291.
Monahan, W.B. and W.D. Koenig. 2005. Estimating the potential effects of sudden oak death on oak-dependent birds. Biological Conservation, 127:146-157.

Goguen, C.B. and M.E. Mathews. 1998. Songbird community composition and nestling success in
grazed and ungrazed pinyon-juniper woodlands. Journal of Wildlife Management. 62(2):474-484
Peterson, A. T. 1993. Adaptive geographic variation in bill shape of Scrub Jays (Aphelocoma coerulescens). Am. Nat. 142:508-527.

Curry, Robert L., A. Townsend Peterson and Tom A. Langen. 2002. Western Scrub-Jay (Aphelocoma californica), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/712
Burt, D.B. 1996. Habitat-use patterns in cooperative and non-cooperative breeding birds: testing predictions with western scrub-jays. The Wilson Bulletin, 108(4):712-727.
Koenig, W.D., A.H. Krakauer, W.B. Monahan, J. Haydock, J.M.H. Knops, and W.J. Carmen. 2009. Mast-producing trees and the geographical ecology of western scrub-jays. Ecography, 32:561-570.
Crosbie, S.P., L.E. Souza, and H.B. Ernest. 2011. Estimating western scrub-jay density in California by multiple-covariate distance sampling. The Condor 113(4):843-852.
Bardwell, E., C.W. Benkman, and W.R. Gould. 2001. Adaptive geographic variation in western scrub-jays. Ecology, 82(9):2617-2627.
habitat_description:
Associated with scrub-oak, pinyon-juniper, chaparral, wooded creek bottoms and brushy ravines (Johnsgard 1979; Zeiner et al., 1990; Curry et al., 2002).  In much of their range, scrub-jays occupy three principal habitats: pinyon, oak, and mixed pinyon-oak woodlands (Peterson, 1993; Bardwell et al. 2001; Curry et al., 2003).

The species frequents scrub and dry woodlands dominated by oaks or pinon pines, but has also adapted well to suburban landscapes (Curry et al. 2002; Crosbie et al., 2011).  Scrub (especially oak, pinon and juniper), brush, chaparral, coastal scrub, oak-pine association; also gardens, orchards, and riparian woodland (Moriarty et al., 1985; Zeiner et al., 1990; Lawrence, 1996; Curry et al. 2002). In some sites in Nevada occurs in pure mountain mahogany shrubland and chaparral habitats without oaks (Curry et al. 2002). Near Colorado Springs, Colorado, western scrub-jays inhabit areas of scrub oak (Quercus gambelii), pinyon pine (Pinus edulis), eastern red cedar (Juniperus virginianus), one-seeded juniper (J. mexicana) and a few ponderosa pines (Pinus ponderosa) (Vierling and Winternitz 2003). Found as a resident in Colfax County, New Mexico in grazed and ungrazed rangeland consisting of blue grama (Bouteloua gracilis), pinyon pine (Pinus edulis), and one-seed juniper (Juniperus monosperma) (Goguen and Mathews 1998).   Found in pinyon-juniper habitat in northeastern New Mexico (Pinus edulis-Juniperus monosperma) (DeMarco et al. 2000). Occurs in pinyon-juniper habitat in the Sandia Mountains in New Mexico (Tatschl 1967).

Occurs in desert riparian woodlands and cactus forests in southern Chihuahuan Desert of Mexico (Curry et al. 2002).
